back_matter.text: Dabasi HHRAO SPECT studies were carried ou± in 50 patients with Rarkinson's disease/PD/,comparing with MRI in all of the cases. The distribution of the patients according to the stages of Hoehn and Yahr was the following I:7, II:12, III:21, IV: i0. 18 patients showed clinical signs of dementia /PDD/ confirmed by psychological examinations. In early phase of RD/StI-II/ hypoperfusion of the bas~ganglia was observed in 6/19 of the cases, while HRI showed no morphological changes. In the late phase of PD/StIII-IV! hypoperfusion of the basal ganglia was found in 7/51 of the cases. Using HRI the presence o3 iron deposit was a common feature in these patients. Decreased bi-or unilateral temporo-parieto-occipital activity was observed in 16 patients, l& of them belonged to the PDD type. Summarizing our ~indings: -The hypoperfusion of ~he basal ganglia shows no correlation with the severity and duration of the disease -The posterior type of cortical hypoperfusion is nearly always present in ROD pa¢ien±s.

DC COSTA, J BROSTOFF, V DOULI and PJ ELL. Institute of Nuclear Medicine and Department of Immunology, UCMSM, London, UK.This study was designed to investigate possible changes in the brain perfusion (rCBF) of patients with Myalgic Encephalomyelitis -Chronic Fatigue Syndrome (ME-CFS), often related to depression.14 ME-CFS patients (age range 17 -51; 6 males and 8 females) had rCBF/SPECT with Tc-99m-HMPAO (550 MBq) and the GE/CGR Neurocam. Quantitative analysis (cerebrum over visual cortex ratios) was carried out comparing data from ME-CFS patients with 24 young, age matched normal volunteers (CONTROL). In addition, 9 old age normal volunteers (age range 71 -79) and 9 old age chronic depression patients (age range 69 -89) were studied, ME-CFS patients showed generalised lower brain perfusion than age matched controls. The most striking and statistically significant abnormalities were found in the following structures: Structure CF$-ME CONTROL p brain stem 0.75+0.05 0. p=0.006 Brain stem perfusion in the old age depressed group (0.85_+0.07) was higher (p=0.001) than ME-CFS patients.In conclusion these data support the evidence that patients with ME-CFS have lower rCBF than normals. They demonstrate, for the first time, hypoperfusion of the brain stem. This finding was not encountered in our cohort of patients with depression. The mesial temporal lobe is involved in the generation and propagation of complex partial seizures in humans.

The neurochemical mechanisms are poorly understood.We have evaluated whether m-AChR and blood flow are altered in the hippocampus and the amygdala in complex partial seizures.Four patients and two normal controls were investigated.The epileptic focus was left-sided as identified by 24 hour-a-day video-scalp-EEG monitoring.SPECT data were recorded interictally (NeuroSPECT, Bitatchi). m-AChR were assessed using 1-123 iododexetimide , and blood flow with Tc-99m HMPAO.Anatomical information was provided by MRI.Regions of interest were drawn on MRI images and transferred onto the co-registered sPBCT images.Data are given as left-to-right ratio of the mean count rate (R). In all four patients, 1-123 IDex to m-AChR was decreased in the anterior hippocampus on the side of the electric abnormality. The hippocampal left-to-right ratio for 1-123 IDex binding was 0.82 + 0.06 (mean ~ SD).There was no asymraetry in 1-123 IDNx binding in amygdala (R=1.02 ~ 0.06).Hippocampal perfusion in patients was syrametric (R=0.97 ~ 0.07).The controls showed no asymmetry in hippocampal 1-123 IDex binding (R=0.99 and 1.00).The results suggest specific changes of hippocampal m-AChR in partial complex epilepsy.The changes may be due to hippocampal cell loss or downregulation of m-AChR secondary to an increase in concentration of e n d o g e n o u s a c e t y l c h o l i n e , a c o n v u l s a n t neurotransmitter. The aim of our study was to investigate the influence of benzodiazepine medication on 1-123-iomazenil (8-defluoro-7-iodo-flumazenil) binding, which has been shown to be a very potent antagonist of central benzodiazepine receptors. 28 studies were performed on 12 benzodiazepine Ireated psychiatric patients, 9 patients after withdrawn of benzodiazepine medication and as control 7 patients without any benzodiazepine treatment. SPECT (double head camera) imaging was performed 10 min and 100 min after application of 200 MBq 1-123 iomazenil. For semiquantitative evaluation of the SPECT images regions of interest which follow anatomical structures of the brain were used. According to PET experiences the specific binding was defined as average counts/pixel in a cortical region minus average counts per pixel in the pons (100 rain p.i.). Results: The specific binding in benzodiazepine treated patients was reduced between 20-80% compared to benzodiazepine free patients. Moreover, benzodiazepine treated patients showed a more rapid wash out. After benzodiazepine withdrawal the activity distribution was found normalized. In conclusion, 1-123 iomazenil can be used to image and to quantify benzodiazepine receptor occupancy by SPECT in humans in relation to different benzodiazepines.

mIn-pentatreotide has been reported to detect somatostatin receptor positive GEP. We examined 24 patients suffering from GEP (predominantly carcinoids, N=15) in whom active disease was established by imaging/invasive procedures (N=6), hormone levels (N=2), or both (N=I6). Single and multiple liver metastases were counted as one. A total of 50 loci was thus verified. Scintigraphy (planar and SPECT) was performed N verified loci 19 18 3 9 focus in the skull firstly detected by pentatreotide scintiqraphy proved to be a meningeoma. Critical analysis of the raise positive and false negative ratios turned out in tavoar of pentatreotide. There is little difference between the results after 4 and 24 h but sensitivity for bone metastases seems to be improved by 24 h-images. in conclusion, mln-pentatreotide is useful in detecting somatostatin receptor positive GEP/metastases. It could have an impact on therapy planning. In this study we concentrate on 2 of them that can be directly tested by muscarinic receptor imaging. One hypothesis is based on the observation that THA at clinical concentrations blocks a substantial amount of muscarinic receptors in animals. A second hypothesis is derived from animal studies that demonstrated significant down-regulation of muscarinic receptors after continued administration of cholinesterase inhibitors. The purpose of this study was to investigate these effects in human subjects after administration of THA. For this purpose quantitative muscarinic receptor imaging was performed in 7 Alzheimer's patients with positron emission tomography (PET) and [11C]tropanyl benzilate (TRB). The subjects were scanned before and 1 week after administration of THA (n=4) or placebo (n=3). The resuhs show an unchanged free muscarinic receptor density in all examined regions (thalamus, striatum and caudate). It is likely that down-regulation would have occured in regions with a high density of cholinergic neurons and receptors (striatum, caudate). Down-regulation was looked for in the thalamus which has many receptors but few cholinergic neurons. We conclude that the disappointing results of THA treatment in Alzheimer patients are not explained by receptor blockage or down-reguIation. Since 1982, the long-acting somatostatin analogue octreotide is available as a therapeutic agent for neuroendocrine somatostatinreceptor positive tumors. For diagnostic purposes, the [123-I-TyrOloctreotide has recently been developed. In preliminary studies with this agent, various tumors with somatostatin receptors were detectable. Due to some limitations of 1-123, the Indium-111 labeled agent [In-111 -DTPA-Phe~]-octreotide has also been developed (Mallinckrodt Inc., Petten, The Netherlands). The in vitro and in vivo binding properties of this new agent have been established and it is currently being investigated in a phase III clinical trial. We report the first results with this agent obtained in two children (2.5 and 8 years old) with stage IV neuroblastoma. Both patients were on chemotherapy during the study. Each child was injected with 30 MBq octreotide. The pre-tested labeling efficiencies were 97.5% and 99.5%. Whole body scans were conducted at 4 and 24 hours p.i. and the results were compared with other imaging modalities and with 1-123-MIBG scans which were performed within 1 week in both patients. In one pat. the IN-OCT showed neuroblastoma lesions (skull, liver, bone) with better image quality than 1-123-MIBG, and showed additionally two bone lesions. The other patient showed an overall weak IN-OCT uptake in a mediastinal lesion which was clearly visualized by 1-123-MIBG, and an MIBG-positive abdominal lesion was completely missed with IN-OCT. Since a close relationship between scan results and presence of receptors can be assumed from in vitro studies, these discrepant preiiminar~ in vivo findings may indicate that the investigated neuroblastomas may have different numbers of receptors or a different status of binding capacity even in the same patient. Large numbers of binding sites for somatoslatin h~ve been detected in-vitro in many tumours arising from central nervous system and endocrine organs. The scintigraphic localization of these receptors offers the possibility to detect metastases or to consider oetreotide therapy.We examined 35 patients with suspected somatostafin receptor bearing tumours(carcinoids n=16; brain and pituitary n=10, pancreatic n=3; gastrinomas n=3; small cell lung cancer n=l; medullary thyroid carcinomas n=2) .Tyr-3-Octreotide as somatostatin receptor analogue was labelled with a chloramin-T-method according to a previous published procedure.Gammacamera images (SIEMENS-ROTA; MICRO-DELTA) were performed 10rain, lh and 4h p.i.;SPECT-images 2h p.i. In 2 patients with islet celt carcinomas somatostatin receptors have been proven in-vitro by autoradiography.In 5 patients a positive therapeutic effect of octreofide was known,in 3 patients octreotide therapy failed.In all 7 patients with evident receptors I2123-TYR-3 -OCTREOTIDE localized the tumours . When treatment failed, no accumulation could be demonstrated. In 4 patients with metastases of careinoids receptors eunld be demonstrated, 12 patients demonstrated no uptake.2 of 3 gastrinomas could be localized. One small cell lung carcinoma had intensive uptake of the tracer. Oliomas demonstrated different uptake in dependence from their histological differentiation.In conclusion ,I-123-TYR-3-OCTREOTIDE is able to localize somatostatin receptors in turnouts. Positive scans are predicitve of a therapeutic effect of octreotide treatment.; negative scans of a negative octreotide effect. back_matter.text: The presence of somatostatin receptors on most GEP tumours offers the possibility for in vivo visualization of such turnours using a radiolabelled somatostatin analogue (OctreoScanRlll, Mallinckmdt Medical, Holland). In order to evaluate the diagnostic value of OctreoScanRll I scintigraphy, we investigated 28 patients with histology proven GEP tumours: 13 caminoids, 2 gasttinomas, 2 MEN-l, 2 nonsecreting tumours, 1 motilinoma. Planar acquisitions were obtained 4 and 24 h after injection of -200MBq OctreoScanR111 and SPECT was performed at 24 h. Scintigraphic resulis were compared with those obtained by morphological imaging methods (CT-scan in all cases, US and MRI).OctreoScanRlll showed lesions in 25 of 28 patients whereas morphological imaging was positive in 22-patients. Among the 3 negative scintiscans, 2 patients (1 gastrinoma, 1 MEN-l) had also negative morphological imaging studies and 1 insulinoma was positive at US only. In 4 of the 25 positive scintiscans no lesions were detected by the other imaging modalities. The primary tumour was visualized in 12 patients by scintigraphy and in 7 patients by morphological imaging. Local turnout recurrence was scintigraphically detected in 6 cases among which only 3 were found with the other techniques. Twenty-seven metastatic sites (13 hepatic) were shown by scintigraphy compared to 21 (12 hepatic) with the morphological imaging methods.In conclusion, Octreoscan~l 11 scintigraphy is a sensitive method for GEP tumour detection providing additional information compared to the morphological imaging methods. It allows to image primary and recurrent tumours as well as metastatic spread during a single diagnostic procedure.
back_matter.section: MORPHOLOGICAL IMAGING AND SOMATOSTATIN RECEPTOR SCINTIGRAPHY OF GASTRO-ENTERO-PANCREATIC (GEP) TUMOURS -A COMPARATIVE STUDY.

back_matter.text: Histamine is known to be effective in some cardiac functions including contractibility and electrical conduction in the heart. These effect may be via to the histamine H-I receptors located in cardiac tissues.The In vivo mouse experiment with C-f1PYR showed that tissue accumulations 30 min. after the injection were 2.2 ~ 0.4, 2.1 ~ 0.4, 5.6 ! 1.4 and 1.6 ~ 0.3 % injected dose/g tissue for atrium,left ventricle, lung, and blood respectively. Blocker injected 5 min before C-II PYR caused a mean 30 % decrease in percentage uptakes of atrium and left ventricle but none in the lung and blood.PET studies done in monreal dog using C-II PYP without blocker and after blocker (diphenhydramine 5 mg/kg) injection showed that cardiac HI receptors can be imaged easily in I0 min and uptake in the heart can be blocked in a maximum ratio.of more than 50 % These results show the possible potential of PET to understand the distribution and the effect of histamine H-I receptors in many cardiac disease in human.
back_matter.section: IN VITRO AND IN VIVO DETERMINATION OF HISTAMINE H-I RECEPTORS IN THE ANIMAL HEARTS.

back_matter.text: In order to localize tumor tissue with photosensitizing agents we have labelled hematoporphyrin and its derivative Photofrin lil with indium-Ill and technetium-99m. Using indium-III-oxine the starting activity was about 400-600 uCi and the concentration of porphyrin 1,5-2 mg/ml bicarbonate buffer pH 7.4. The vial was incubated at 110-140 C for 20 min and allowed to cool before the next step. Using the same incubation conditions with indium-Ill-chloride the initial activity was 500-600 uCi and pH was adjusted with 5% NaHC03 to 7.0 pH. After labelling the products were purified using reversed phase C18-cartridge$ activated with 5 ml of methanol and I ~ mol/I NH4-acetate buffer, pH 5.2. The reaction mixture was diluted with the same buffer before passing through the C18-cartridge. After washing with buffer and 20% methanol, the labelled product was eluted with acetonitrile: methanol (60:40, v/v). About 10 mCi of 99m-pertechnetate was reduced with stannous chloride (0.25 ml, 0.2 mg/ml) before labelling porphyrins. After 10 min the pH of the solution was adjusted to 7.4 with citrate solution and immediately after that 2.5 mg of porphyrin was slowly added to the vial. Labelling was performed within 30 min at room temperature. The labelling efficiency was good using both indium chloride and pertechnetate, 85-90%. Both reactions were affected by pH. When the pH diverged from the optimum of 7.4, labelling either did not occur or the efficiency was only 10-20%. With indium oxine solution the labelling efficiency was about 70%.
back_matter.section: LABELLING OF HEMATOPORPHYRIN AND POLYPORHYRIN WITH INDIUM--Ill AND TECHNETIUM-99m

back_matter.text: Availability of Tc-99m sestamibi (MIBI) is limited especially in emergency cases due to the time-constmdng labeling procedure requiring a 10-min boiling water bath and a 30-rain radiochemical purity (RCP) analysis. These two restrictions have been surmounted by the combined use of a microwave oven (Me) heating method and a mini-paper chrcmatography (MPC) system. However, use of the Me presents sc~e potential problems: I) technical error in setting Me heating time and power setting; 2) ejection of the rubber septiml if vial is not evacuated; 3) breakage o~ vial during MO heating process; 4) inconsistent and inhe~Dgeneous M0 heating. Although a l-rain boiling water bath time is sufficient to provide an acceptable labeling efficiency of MIBI, an additional tin~ of 20-25 rain is required to heat the water to a boiling state. This study was undertaken to evaluate the use of an instant hot water machine to prepare MIBI. This device is commonly used to supply hot water (86.2+1.9°C, n=45) for preparing instant food (e.g., coffee, ~ea, etc.). Three milliliters of 5,500 MBq Tc-99m were added to a MIBI kit and then placed in a 150-mi insulated beaker filled with water frc~ an instant hot water machine. MPC was used to determine RCP of samples after i, 1.5, 2, 3, 4, and 5 rain incubation periods. Our results indicate that 2 rain was the shortest incubation time which yielded an acceptable RCP of 94.7+0.4% (n=60) over the 24-hr evaluation time. The use of an instant hot water m~chine not only avoids those probl(~s associated with the MO heating method but also provides a rapid, efficient, and relatively simple option for preparation of MIBI. Pl~telets seem to have great importance in the diagnosis of different thrombotic diseases. 9?mTc-HH-PAO has bee~ evaluated as an aBent ~o radiolabel h~man olatelets in vitro. back_matter.text: OF 5- IODO-NICOTINAMIDE FOR BRAIN STUDIES Nicotinamide (NAM) is a potential marker for studying brain metabolism.It may be useful in the study of nervous disorders caused by vitamin deficiencies. In our study we developed a convenient labelling method of producing iodine (I-123, 1-131) -NAM for biodistribution studies which we have done in rats.Incorporation of iodine in NAM may have a significant effect on its biological properties.Also the lipophilicity of NAM is increased and the cerebral uptake may be increased when iodine is incorporated in NAM. NAM was labelled with iodine in the 5position by halogen exchange reaction. was synthesized from 5bromo-nicotinic acid (Aldrich).Br-nicotinic acid was acylated with thionyl chloride and the product was reacted with ammonia to produce Br-NAM. Proton-NMR spectra was obtained from the Br-nicotinic acid and from the purified Br-NAM. Iodine NAM was made by heating in the presence of catalyst and glacial acid.Iodine NAM was purified by RP-HPLC. Labelling percentage after exchange reaction was >90 %.After purification the radiochemical purity of the product determined by HPLC was >98 % and the specific activity of 1-123-NAM was >655 GBq/mg.In conclusion a method of producing iodine labelled NAM was developed.

Our investigations on the development of new myocardial perfusion imaging agents have been extended to cationic phenanthroline complexes of Tc(II). The complexes were synthesized by reduction of pertechnetate with sodium borohydride in the presence of 1, 10-phenanthroline (phen), 4-methyl-or 5-methyl-l,10phenanthroline. After purification by HPLC the complexes were characterized by IR/VIS-UV spectrophotometry and magnetic susceptibility measurements demonstrating the d J configuration of Tc(II).. For biodistribution evaluation in mice, [99mTc(phen)]2+ was obtained with a reaction yield of 12% and radiochemical purity of 92.5%. The rather hydrophilic complex was predominantly excreted by the kidneys. Its low blood retention resulted in a heart/blood ratio of 4.2 at 100 min post-injection which may be improved by synthesizing the analogous complex of Tc(I) and/or by using suitable phenanthroline derivatives as ligands. In 1989 the successful use of gadolinium phthaleincemplexone as a hepatobillary NMR contrast agent in rabbits has been described (KAWAMURA et al.) . As this complex was applied obviously without preceding isolation and characterization, we wanted to improve the chemical aspects of that work. Trials to reproduce the poor production data failed, but we succeeded in synthesizing a new gadolinium phthaleincomplexone compound (Gd-PC) which could be isolated, purified and characterized by normal methods of analytical chemistry. Additionally the same complex labelled with the short lived gamma emitter 6 h) was produced with regard to biodistribufion studies In animals.Our synthesis is carried out by adding a solution of gadolinium nitrate to a diluted solution of phthalein complexone in the heat. The resulting crude product can be purified by gel chromatography. For labelling with , produced in a nuclear reactor, the synthesis procedure was scaled down by a factor of 103 . In contrast to the results of KAWAMURA our Gd-PC is sparingly soluble in water, but it can be sohited easily in isotonic sodium hydrogencarbonate solution. Whereas the ultraviolett spectrum of the compound differs only unessentially from that of the free phthalein complexone, the infrared spectrum shows some significant differences. Like the broad peaks in the NMR spectrum this points out to complexation. As a result of FAB mass spectrometry and activation analysis the molar ratio of gadolinium to phthalein complexune in the purified substance seems to be 1 : 1. The labelled product was shown to be identical with the inactive compound. 67-70 (1989) .
